bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas and Lydia Cabrera, November 23, 1953

div1.p: Hench inquires about his Finlay medal and an upcoming nutrition conference.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas and Lydia Cabrera, November 23, 1953
div1.opener:
November 23, 1953
Miss Maria Teresa Rojas
Miss Lydia Cabrera
Quinta San Jose
Calzada Real
Marianao, Habana, Cuba
My dear Tina and Lydia:
div1.p:
I have had a very nice letter from Mrs. Smith inviting me to visit Havana
during a Nutrition Week to say something, presumably at a press conference,
in behalf of the importance of nutrition and presumably to receive a decora-
tion at that time. Please see the letter which I have sent to her.

I find it a little difficult to plan anything definite yet; first of all, be-
cause I have heard nothing official regarding the decoration and have not
heard from you and Mrs. Smith whether those who have so graciously decided
to give me the decoration want to do it at that time; and secondly, the
invitation from Mrs. Smith merely to make some remarks regarding nutrition
at a press conference finds me a little uncertain as I am not a nutritionist
but a rheumatologist. I will certainly need help from Doctors Williams and
Harris regarding this matter.

May I tell you in confidence (although you can discuss it with Mrs. Smith
if you choose to do so) that we members of the staff must report to the ap-
propriate committee here the purpose of the trips that we take on clinic time.
I feel certain that the committee would permit me to go to Cuba briefly to
accept this high honor and they would be quite willing for me to help
sponsor nutrition week at the same time, but I don't believe that they would
want me to go to Cuba just for a press conference if there was nothing else
involved, that is no meeting and so on. Of course I am allowed to go where
I want on my vacation time but I must be careful in planning this as I have
already promised (as I wrote you before) tentatively to make a quick trip
to Stockholm next fall, which trip will have to be on vacation time. If
you or Mrs. Smith can assure me of two things, that would help me greatly
in planning the Havana trip: (1) that Doctors Williams and Harris, the scientific
advisors for Nutrition Week, want me to come and will help me plan what to
say, realizing that I am a rheumatologist, not a nutritionist, and (2) that
the same visit will be agreeable regarding the matter of the decoration.

It will be nice indeed to see you if this works out but, as I said before,
I have had no official word of any sort from the Cuban Government.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
